[[Houston]], Texas, United States | origin = | instrument = [[Human voice|Vocals]], [[guitar]] | genre = [[Texas blues]], [[electric blues]] | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]], [[guitarist]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = 1950s–2008 | label = Various | associated_acts = | website = }} '''Pete Mayes''' (March 21, 1938 – December 16, 2008){{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2008b.html |title=2008 July to December |publisher=The Dead Rock Stars Club |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}} was an [[United States|American]] [[Texas blues]] [[singing|singer]], [[guitarist]] and [[songwriter]]. He was variously known as '''Texas Pete Mayes''' and '''T-Bone Man'''; the latter a reference to his guitar playing resembling his hero, [[T-Bone Walker]]. Mayes' made few [[sound recording and reproduction|recordings]] but ''For Pete's Sake'' was released in 1998, nearly fifty years after Mayes first appeared on stage. It was his most widely distributed recording, and won the [[Blues Foundation]]'s [[Blues Music Award|W.C. Handy Award]] for 'comeback album of the year'.{{cite web |first= |last= |url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/front/6169500.html|title=Obituary by Andrew Dansby |publisher=Chron.com - ''[[Houston Chronicle]]''|accessdate=December 29, 2009}} ==Biography== '''Floyd Davis Mayes''' was born and raised in [[Double Bayou, Texas|Double Bayou]], [[Texas]]. The town was home to a [[dance hall]], which played a significant part in Mayes' life.{{cite web|author=Richard Skelly |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/pete-mayes-mn0000266882/biography |title=Pete Mayes | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-28}} As a child he learned with a cheap guitar without a full set of strings and practiced for hours each day. Mayes was aged 16 when T-Bone Walker invited him on stage to perform. In the early 1950s, Mayes played with various [[musical ensemble|bands]] at his local dance hall. After several years he led his own group, opening the show for touring musicians. While in the [[United States Army]], Mayes worked with The Contrasts, which comprised three white and three black musicians. Mayes learned from watching T-Bone Walker and [[Gatemouth Brown]], and he later cited Walker, [[B.B. King]], [[Kenny Burrell]], plus [[Lowell Fulson]] as major influences. In 1960 Mayes relocated to [[Houston]], and during the following decade he played with Fulson, [[Big Joe Turner]], [[Percy Mayfield]], [[Bill Doggett]], and [[Junior Parker]]. Mayes also toured with the [[jazz]] musicians, [[Count Basie]] and [[Dizzy Gillespie]]. Unable to make a living as a full-time musician, Mayes worked as a [[ranch hand]] and then as a [[House painter and decorator|painter]] for the [[Houston Independent School District]]. He retired from the latter job with disability pay. Mayes did perform whenever possible. He undertook tours in the 1970s and played frequently in the 1990s, even though his health had started to fail. In 1983, he inherited from an uncle ownership of his local dance hall. In 1986, Double Trouble Records of the [[Netherlands]] issued ''Texas Guitar Master'', which included a live 'Battle of the Guitars' with Joe "Guitar" Hughes.{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray | edition= | publisher= Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | page= 120 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}} In 1996, Mayes appeared on the bill of the [[Long Beach Blues Festival]]. By the time ''For Pete's Sake'' was released (1998), Mayes was still actively managing the Double Bayou dance hall. Following years of ill health, which included heart problems, [[diabetes mellitus|diabetes]] and the amputation of both legs, Mayes died in Houston in December 2008, aged 70. Mayes was survived by his wife, son and a brother. ==Selected discography== ===Albums=== *''For Pete's Sake'' (1998) - Antone's *''Live!
